facts.text: The crushing process terminated on March 12, 1959, and on that day about 1,000 of the 1,600 seasonal workers left for their homes by the evening after receiving all their dues.
The remaining seasonal workers continued to work in the factory till March 16, 1959.
Appellants employ about 1,600 seasonal workers and about 650 permanent workers.
Evidence of W.W.1, B.S. Chauhan, shows that seasonal workers other than those who left on March 12, 1959, were borne on the muster roll on March 13, 1959; not challenged in cross-examination.
Appellants' witness Shri K.K. Sinha, Manufacturing Chemist, was not working in the mills in the 1958-59 crushing season.
Total seasonal workers 1,600; nearly 1,000 left March 12, so about 600 continued till March 16.
All ancillary operations in the factory came to an end and entire machinery was at a standstill on March 16, 1959.

Award of Industrial Tribunal in Reference No. 33 of 1953 dated April 15, 1953: 'All permanent workers and such seasonal employees as are on the factoryâ€™s roll on the day following the close of the crushing season will be entitled to the closure holidays.'

legal_issues.text: Whether the crushing season of 1958-59 must be deemed to have ended on March 12, 1959 when the actual crushing of sugar cane stopped or on March 16, 1959 when all ancillary operations in the factory came to an end and the entire machinery was at a standstill.

petitioner_arguments.text: Crushing season came to an end on March 16, 1959 which was the last day on which the factory was worked; only seasonal workers borne on muster roll on March 17, 1959 entitled to three days closure holidays.
Fact that between March 12 and March 16, 1959, 600 seasonal workers continued to work has not been established.

respondent_arguments.text: Crushing season came to an end on March 12, 1959; remaining seasonal workers who continued till March 16 entitled to three days closure holidays under 1953 award.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Award in Reference No. 33 of 1953 dated April 15, 1953

court_reasoning.text: Proceed on basis that about 600 seasonal workers continued to be borne on muster roll on March 13, 1959, as per unchallenged evidence of W.W.1 and lack of counter-evidence from appellants.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Number of continuing workers established as 600.

court_reasoning.text: Crushing season must be deemed to have ended on date crushing operations came to an end (March 12, 1959), not when all manufacturing processes ended; give expression 'crushing season' its ordinary meaning unless industry meaning shown.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence that 'crushing season' meant period factory actually working beyond crushing operations.

court_reasoning.text: 1953 Award's Clause 3 indicates 'crushing season' means period during which crushing operations carried on; nothing to indicate otherwise.

holdings.text: Crushing season of 1958-59 ended on March 12, 1959.

outcome.summary: The appeal by special leave is dismissed, upholding that the crushing season ended on March 12, 1959, entitling seasonal workers on the muster roll on March 13, 1959 to three days closure holidays as per the 1953 award.
outcome.relief_granted: Seasonal workers (about 600) entitled to three days closure holidays

key_quotes.text: It seems to us clear that the crushing season must be deemed to have ended on the date on which the crushing operations in the factory came to an end and not on the date on which the manufacturing processes in the factory came to an end.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We must give to the expression crushing season its ordinary meaning, unless it is shown that in the industry it has acquired some other meaning.
key_quotes.speaker: court
